awd_abstract_narration:
This REU site in Mechanobiology at the Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) College of Engineering will annually engage a diverse cohort of undergraduate students and faculty members in biomedical engineering research projects in areas related to mechanobiology. Mechanobiology is an emerging field at the interface of biology and engineering that focuses on how physical forces and changes in the mechanical properties of cells and tissues contribute to development, physiology, and disease. The field of mechanobiology is a rapidly expanding research area that requires a unique set of interdisciplinary skills. The individual projects in this REU program will be focused on gaining interdisciplinary skills related to cell mechanics, mechanobiology in drug delivery, pulmonary mechanics, and orthopedic regenerative medicine. Furthermore, trainees will learn the basic scientific method, statistics skills, research ethics, and the workings of collaborative biomedical research laboratories. 

This 10 week summer REU site has 3 goals for the participants. The first goal is to increase participation in mechanobiology research. The second goal is to provide opportunities to enhance scientific literacy and communication at the interface of engineering and life sciences.  The third goal is to prepare trainees for graduate study or research careers in mechanobiology or related fields. The students will be equipped with cutting-edge research skills in mechanobiology including microfabricated post arrays, mechanotransduction pathway analysis, FRET-based force sensing, cell-material interactions, and mechanically enabled drug delivery. Student participants will also participate in a local outreach activity that enhances engineering knowledge of K-12 students and teachers. At weekly meetings, students will learn about research techniques, participate in journal clubs, and hear talks from experts in mechanobiology. At the end of each summer, students will participate in a research symposium and draft abstracts to present their work at a national engineering meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
We held the NSF REU Site: Mechanobiology at VCU for 3 summers, with the summer of 2020 cancelled due to COVID-19. As a part of the site, we funded and trained 28 students, with 4 additional students funded on PI NSF REU supplements or other funding sources that were added to the Mechanobiology cohort for outreach, professional development, and social events. Of these 32 students, 22 self-identified as female and 10 self-identified as male. Of the 32 students, 24 reported being from an underrepresented minority in science or engineering including one or more of the following: gender identity and expression, race and ethnicity (African Americans/Blacks, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders), disability, LGBTQ+, first-generation college, and socio-economic status.

 Intellectual Merit:  Achieving goals Our prior REU site had the following goals: 1. To increase students? participation in mechanobiology research 2. To provide opportunities to enhance scientific literacy and communication at the interface of engineering and life sciences 3. To prepare students for graduate study or research careers in mechanobiology or related fields. We performed surveys and focus groups on REU student participants and their mentors and evaluations reflected that we met these goals. Abstracts and Publications: From the REU Site we have had 25 abstracts to national meetings accepted. 21 of these were presented in the years 2019 and 2021. The majority of these abstracts were presented in talks and posters at the Biomedical Engineering Society Meeting, but we have also had REU student presentations and posters at the Orthopedic Research Society, The American Urological Association, and the Summer Meeting of Biomechanics, Bioengineering, and Biotransport. Of note, one of our students won awards for best poster at the Orthopedic Research Society Meeting. In addition to published abstracts, 2 peer reviewed publications have resulted thus far from the REU Site with participants as co-authors. At least 4 additional peer reviewed publications are anticipated with REU students as co-authors based on papers under review and in preparation. Broader Impacts:  Preparing a diverse workforce in STEM Our REU Site contributed to the professional development of the students. Of the 33 total students trained, 8 are currently in PhD Programs (2 of the 8 at VCU) in Biomedical Engineering or a related field, 2 are in MD programs, 4 are in biomedical industry positions, and 16 are completing their undergraduate programs at their home institutions. Outreach Success  As part of the REU Site, we asked that all students in the cohort participate in at least one outreach activity. In 2019 we had 100% REU student participation in outreach, in 2021 and 2022 we had 80% participation in outreach. The students who did not participate reported that it was due to limited opportunities due to fewer in person outreach events. Examples of outreach projects included: Garden Clean up at Carver Elementary School, STEAM Nights, Mission Tomorrow (8th grade outreach activity), and K-12 STEM Teacher Training. Many of our students participated in more than one outreach activity. The College of Engineering at VCU believes that it is the duty of those at public universities to not only give back to the community but also to allow the community to inform the work at the university.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2023
Modified by: Rebecca Heise
